metadata.case_name: Pfizer Private Ltd. v. Its Employees

facts.text: Two items of dispute referred to Industrial Tribunal, Bombay by Government of Maharashtra under ss. 10 and 12 of Industrial Disputes Act 1947 on 22nd January 1962: (1) reduction of paid holidays from 27 to 8; (2) introduction of three shifts via notice under s. 9A.

Tribunal award dated June 9, 1962 rejected appellant's case for three shifts; substantially accepted reduction of holidays to 10 per year in consultation with respondents, plus additional increment from 1st August 1962.

Appellant Pfizer Private Ltd., incorporated under Indian Companies Act 1913, manufactures life-saving drugs like antibiotics, anti-tubercular drugs (including P.A.S.), vitamin products at Bombay factory; receives raw products from Chandigarh factory.

Factory previously worked multiplicity of shifts with underutilization of machinery and raw materials; inadequate production failed to meet market demand; sought three shifts for larger production, better quality, exports, competition.
P.A.S. production (developed 1960-61) is continuous process requiring three shifts for quality improvement; post-purification processes take 20 hours.

Employees enjoyed 5-day week and public holidays under Negotiable Instruments Act (27 in relevant year); resisted three shifts as it would convert to 6-day week, increase workload, depart from pharmaceutical industry pattern.
Employees willing to work two Saturdays per month with overtime; proposed two shifts instead; disputed P.A.S. as continuous process.

Tribunal found pharmaceutical factories in Greater Bombay mostly one or two shifts; three shifts only in some chemical sections; night work prejudicial; P.A.S. not requiring continuous three shifts; rejected three shifts but allowed interim third shift in P.A.S. department for one year with 10% extra pay.

Factory employs 821 workmen, 235 girls; s.66(1)(b) Factories Act limits women to 6AM-7PM; current departments: (1) P.A.S. etc. three shifts, 125 employees, 43 hrs/week; (2) one shift 5-day, 75 employees; (3) two shifts 5-day, 456 employees; (4) one shift 5-day, 165 employees.
Proposed three shifts: increase working hours by 1-1/4 hrs (net 55 mins/week), end 5-day week; rotate male workers; hire additional hands.
National emergency context requires increased production; capital, labour responsive to community needs.

Evidence: Dr. Joshi (expert) on P.A.S. continuous process, 65% rejection in Jan 1962 due to M.A.P.; processes post-purification take 20 hrs; confirmed by lab records. Respondent's Mr. Pillai conceded 18.5 hrs.
Pharma industry pattern: some factories (Sandoz, Raptakos, Merck etc.) have three shifts in chemical/pharma sections.
Girl employees' inconvenience: early 7:20AM start hard for some from Thana, risk of molestation.
Standing Order 10(1)(a) allows multiple shifts at Manager's discretion; employees liable to transfer.
Appellant willing to pay extra for shifts (paying 12% night, 8% second shift); remit to Tribunal for decision.
Public holidays: 27 under Negotiable Instruments Act; other states/GOI have fewer (14-18); Tribunal reduced to 10.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant justified in introducing three shifts in factory, including P.A.S. section as continuous process, considering industry pattern, employee interests, national emergency.
Whether reduction of paid holidays from 27 (Negotiable Instruments Act) reasonable, especially post allowance of three shifts.

petitioner_arguments.text: Three shifts needed for full machinery utilization, better raw material use, meet demand, exports, competition; P.A.S. continuous process (Dr. Joshi evidence); industry examples; Standing Orders permit; willing to pay extra.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.9A Industrial Disputes Act; Standing Orders under Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act 1946; ss.51,59,66 Factories Act

respondent_arguments.text: Three shifts convert 5-day to 6-day week, night work prejudicial, increase workload, depart from Bombay pharma pattern (1-2 shifts); P.A.S. not continuous; willing for two Saturdays with OT or two shifts.
27 holidays term of employment; no justification for reduction to 10.

court_reasoning.text: National emergency demands increased production; Tribunal erred ignoring this; pattern not rigid, chemical sections have three shifts; P.A.S. continuous (accept Dr. Joshi over Pillai); allow three shifts subject to Tribunal deciding extra pay.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Imperative national needs override doctrinaire opposition to night work/6-day week.

court_reasoning.text: 5-day week/night rest ideals for future high economy; now, compensate extra work; inconvenience plea weak; Standing Orders contemplate shifts but Tribunal scrutinizes reasonableness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant enlightened employer; will ensure healthy conditions.

court_reasoning.text: 27 holidays high (vs other states 14-18); reduce to 16; Tribunal's 10 partly because rejected shifts, now adjust.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not bound by Negotiable Instruments Act holidays for factories.

holdings.text: Appellant entitled to introduce three shifts per notice under s.9A; remit to Tribunal for additional payment decision; interim continues till then.
Reduce paid holidays to 16 per year.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of disputes; notice of change.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Max 48 hrs/week, overtime, women hours limit.

outcome.summary: Appeal No.625/1962 (Pfizer) allowed: three shifts permitted subject to Tribunal deciding additional compensation. Appeal No.626/1962 (employees) allowed in part: holidays reduced to 16 instead of Tribunal's 10. Both appeals allowed with modifications.
outcome.relief_granted: Three shifts allowed post-remand; holidays fixed at 16/year.

key_quotes.text: "in the face of the present national emergency, the complexion of the problem has completely changed. The whole economy of the country is now being put on a war basis"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Shifts focus to production needs overriding employee preferences.

key_quotes.text: "all legitimate efforts made by the employer to produce more and more of the goods required for the community must receive the co-operation of the employees-of course, on reasonable terms."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Balances employer production goals with employee compensation.
